attributes.title: Effect of Fenugreek on vasomotor symptoms in menopausal women: Protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description:
Background: Vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes or night sweats) are closely related to the impaired quality of life in menopausal women. Fenugreek is the ripe seed of Trigonella foenum graecum Linn. In China, this plant is used to relieve menopausal symptoms in women. Although recent studies have shown that fenugreek may have a good effect on the menopausal symptoms, there is no meta-analysis to systematically evaluate its efficacy in improving menopausal vasomotor symptoms.
Methods: Randomized controlled trials that met the inclusion criteria will be retrieved in Five English online databases and four Chinese online databases. The primary outcomes are changes in frequency and intensity of vasomotor symptoms that measured by validated scales. The secondary outcomes will include quality of life, blood hormone parameters, blood biochemical parameters, and adverse events. Heterogeneity of data will be assessed by I2 and Cochrane’s Q statistics. Sensitivity analysis and subgroup analysis will be performed to explore the sources of heterogeneity. Egger's test and Begg’s test will be used to assess the publication bias. Finally, we will evaluate the quality of evidence by the GRADE approach. All the data statistics will be performed using the STATA 15.0 software.
Results: All the results of will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

q2.value: Fenugreek could improve menopausal vasomotor symptoms.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
1. Inclusion and exclusion criteria
1.1. Study design 
Only randomized controlled trials (RCTs) will be included in our study. Non-RCTs, observational studies, real-world studies, reviews, case reports, and animal experiments will be excluded.
1.2. Participants
women who were experiencing vasomotor symptoms due to menopausal, perimenopausal or postmenopausal period will be included. Women with vasomotor symptoms due to breast cancer treatment or surgical menopause will be excluded.
1.3. Interventions
The intervention of the test group was fenugreek or fenugreek extract, and the control group was placebo-controlled. Moreover, studies using fenugreek or its extract as part of the compound prescription will not be included.
1.4. Outcomes
The primary outcomes are changes in frequency and intensity of vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes or night sweats). The vasomotor symptoms must be measured by the Cooperman’s index, Kupperman Index, Greene Climacteric scale, Menopause Rating Scale, or any other criteria for measuring menopausal symptoms. The secondary outcomes will include quality of life (based on generic validated scales), blood hormone parameters, blood biochemical parameters, and adverse events.
2. Study search
Two authors (Tingchao Wu and Mingmin He) will independently search the online databases (including PubMed, Embase, Web of Science, Cochrane Library, ClinicalTrials.gov, China National Knowledge Internet, VIP Information Chinese Periodical Service Platform, Wanfang Data Knowledge Service Platform, and Chinese Biomedicine Literature Database) for identifying the relevant studies. The search strategies will be performed using the Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) terms and free-text words. There will be no restrictions on the language and time of publication. 
3. Study selection
EndNote X9 software will be used to manage the retrieved literature. Two independent authors (Tingchao Wu and Mingmin He) will screen the retrieved literature according to the inclusion and exclusion criteria. In the first step, the duplicated literature will be removed, and then the titles and abstracts will be reviewed. Subsequently, the full-text of the relevant literature will be investigated to assess their suitability for meta-analysis. Any discrepancies will be resolved by discussion with the corresponding author (Rensong Yue). 
4. Data extraction
We will extract relevant data from the included articles based on the following items: first Author; year of publication; country; study design; sample size (test/control group); age (test/control group); intervention (dosage form, dosage and duration of trial); outcomes in the test and control groups; Safety parameter and adverse event. If the data we need are not available in an article, we will try to obtain it by contacting the original investigators.
5. Risk of bias assessment
Two investigators (Tingchao Wu and Mingmin He) will independently assesse the quality of the included studies according to the Cochrane Collaboration risk of bias tool. The content of the evaluation will cover six domains of bias: selection bias (“random sequence generation” and “allocation concealment”), performance bias (“blind of participants and personnel”), detection bias (“blinding of outcome assessment”), attrition bias (“incomplete outcome data”), reporting bias (“selective reporting”), and other bias. Any discrepancies will be judged by consultation with the corresponding author. 
6. Data analysis
The STATA 15.0 software will be used for data statistics. For continuous data, mean difference (MD) between groups will be calculated if outcomes were reported on the same scale, while standardized mean difference will be calculated if outcomes were reported on different scales. Heterogeneity of the included studies will be assessed by I2 and Cochrane’s Q statistics. I2 < 50% with P > 0.05 indicate that there is no significant heterogeneity, the fixed-effect model will be used to combine effect sizes; otherwise, the random-effect model will be applied. The overall effects with P-value less than 0.05 will be considered statistically significant.
7 Subgroup analysis
To better explore the sources of heterogeneity, subgroup analyses will be performed based on the following moderator variables: geographical area of subjects, assessment scale, dosage of fenugreek, dosage form of fenugreek, and intervention duration.
8. Sensitivity analysis
Sensitivity analysis will be used to evaluate the stability of the overall results by removing each trial sequentially. Then we will focus on the comparison of the pooled effect size and heterogeneity before and after sensitivity analysis.
9. Publication bias assessment
If more than 10 trials are finally included in our study, Egger's linear regression test and Begg’s test will be used to assess the potential publication bias. P-value less than 0.05 will be considered as statistically significant.
10. Grading the quality of evidence
The GRADE approach will be used to evaluate the quality of evidence for the entire study. The evaluation includes five domains: risk of bias (study design and execution), imprecision, indirectness, inconsistency, and publication bias. Each domain will be defined as “very low”, “low”, “moderate” or “high”.

attributes.title: Psychological Antecedents of Consumer Self-development
attributes.description: A second deviation form the preregistered data screening procedure.

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

outliers.value:
Original preregistered data screening procedure: 

Duplicate participant IDs will be identified and the second entry removed. Any participant who withdraws based on the exit consent will be removed. Data screening prior to any analyses will be conducted on the following attention/quality checks: (a) the Conscientious Responder scale, where three out of five items must be correctly answered; (b) responding “yes” to the self-report attention check item; (c) correct responses to the single item comprehension check; (d) any participant who uses a single response throughout will be removed (e.g., responding with all “1’s”); (e) no greater than a 5 minute break between the manipulation and the outcome measures, (f) screen out if participants who do not meaningfully respond to the “saying is believing” task (in other words, participants must follow the instructions); and (g) reading speed (i.e., reading more than 300 wpm; Brysbaert, 2019). Two manipulation checks are used for the mindset manipulation: (a)	Check #1: The article was “difficult to understand,” “credible,” “persuasive,” rated on a 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree); (b) Check #2:  implicit theory questionnaire, rated on a 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree) point scale. Anyone who disagree with the intended direction of each article (i.e., those who, on average, disagree with the article—those who indicate the mid-point and below) will be removed before data analysis. 


Deviation #2 from preregistered data screening procedure:

Upon screening out poor quality responses based on the above criteria, it was observed that the reading speed criteria (item g, above) removed a substantial amount of participants.  

Of the remaining 210 participants, 61 participants read faster than 300 wpm (i.e., were below 4.3 min or 260 sec). 

We decided to retain all participants in the sample for two reasons: (a) these participants read the article well enough to provide “meaningful” responses in the previous “saying-is-believing” task, (b) this criteria may have been too strict given the large number of participants identified. 

We are therefore excluding this reading speed check from the data screening procedure on the basis that this check too strictly removes participants. 

Deviation #3 from preregistered data screening procedure:

Upon screening out responses based on the manipulation check, it was observed that a disproportionate amount of participants in the fixed mindset condition would be screened out.  

Of the remaining 210 participants, 33 participants in the fixed mindset condition were below the mid-point of the fixed mindset subscale and 13 participants in the growth mindset condition were below the mid-point on the growth subscale. Given this manipulation check disproportionately removes participants from the fixed mindset condition, we will retain all 210 participants in the main analyses. 

We are therefore excluding this manipulation check criteria from the data screening procedure on the basis that disproportionately removes participants. 

There have been no other deviations from the data screening procedure. No analyses have been performed at this point.

attributes.title: Protocol - Fluoroquinolones and the risk of aortic aneurysm or dissection: systematic review
attributes.description:
**Type of project:** Systematic review

**Principal Investigator and guarantor:** Daniel Caldeira, MD, PhD.

**Institution:** Faculdade de Medicina da Universidade de Lisboa, Portugal.

Departments: CCUL - Centro Cardiovascular da Universidade de Lisboa; Laboratory of Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics, Faculdade de Medicina, Universidade de Lisboa, Portugal. 

*Project aimed to be the Master Thesis of Nuno Vouga Ribeiro (Medicine Student)*

Funding: None.


----------


**PICOS data:**

Patients: All patients

Intervention: Fluoroquinolones

Comparator/Control: No fluoroquinolones / beta-lactams

Outcome: Risk orf aortic disease (aneurysm/dissection)

Study design: Randomized controlled trials; Controlled longitudinal observational studies


----------


**Brief Methodological and Statistical Analysis Plan:**

Databases for Search: MEDLINE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), Web of Science Core Collection

Meta-analysis planned: Yes. Review Manager 5.3 and/or STATA 12

Risk of Bias evaluation: Cochrane RoB tool 2.0 and ROBINS-I

Pooled data confidence evaluation: GRADE.

----------
**Milestones:**

Project Initiation: March 2019

Literature Search Date: March 2019

Expected Project end: April/May 2020

attributes.title: The State of Renal Sympathetic Denervation for The Management of Patients with Hypertension: A Systematic Review & Meta-analysis
attributes.description: Sympathetic nervous system plays a central role in the development and persistence of essential hypertension. In recent years renal sympathetic denervation (RSD) has emerged as a promising option for the treatment of patients with hypertension. We aim to conduct a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) comparing the efficacy of RSD to sham procedure in the management of hypertension

summary.value:
Search Strategy: We will conduct a literature search of PubMed, EMBASE, Cochrane library, Clinicaltrials.gov and Conference proceedings, from inception through April 22, 2020. The search strategy will combine the terms “Hypertension”, “Blood Pressure” “Renal Denervation”, “Renal Sympathetic Denervation” and “Sympathetic Denervation”. We will utilize the “related articles” function in PubMed to find relevant articles which are missed by the initial search. In addition, reference lists of included studies will be hand searched to further locate relevant articles that are missed by the primary search. Our search and meta-analysis will be conducted and reported according to Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Protocols (PRISMA-P) Statement 2015.  
Study selection: Titles and abstracts of studies will be screened by two authors. The full texts of relevant articles will be reviewed to determine if the study meet the inclusion criteria. Any discrepancies will be resolved by a third author.
Inclusion criteria: To be included in the current analysis, the study has to fulfill all of the following criteria: (1) randomized controlled trial , (2) includes patients with hypertension treated by RSD, (3) control group treated by sham procedure, (4) reported the outcomes of interest. (4) study is in English language and full text published in peer-review journal.
Outcomes and definitions: The outcomes of interest will include: (1) change in 24-hour ambulatory systolic blood pressure (ASBP), (2) change in 24-hour ambulatory diastolic blood pressure (ADBP), (3) change in office systolic blood pressure (OSBP), (4) change in office diastolic blood pressure(ODBP). All the outcomes were analyzed at the maximum follow up provided by the included RCTs.
Quality assessment: The methodological quality and risk of bias of included studies will be evaluated using the Cochrane Collaboration’s tool for risk of bias. 
Statistical analysis: The meta-analysis outcomes will be pooled using Mantel-Hansel random effects model. DerSimonian and Laird method will be used for estimation of heterogeneity. We will use the random effect model to account for potential statistical heterogeneity. Summary estimates will be calculated as weighted mean difference (WMD) with 95% confidence intervals (CI). Sensitivity analysis will be performed on primary outcomes by exclusion of one trial at a time. Heterogeneity between studies will be explored by Cochran Q statistic (p<0.05) and I-squared (I2) statistic. All statistical tests will be two-sided and P values <0.05 will be considered significant.   
 To account for heterogeneity  in study designs, we will stratify our analysis  based on  following categories  of studies : (a)  based on medication status by dividing the studies into those which allowed the patients to be on antihypertensive medications (ON Medication) versus studies which mandated all patients to be off antihypertensive medications (OFF Medication) and (b)  based on the whether a first generation monopolar catheter versus second generation multipolar  catheter was used  (First versus Second generation trials). Furthermore, to study the effect of difference in duration of follow up between the trials , we will perform an additional analysis looking at the heterogeneity of the treatment effect by dividing the studies into two groups, studies which report outcomes at > 3 month of follow-up versus studies reporting the outcomes at ≤ 3 month of follow up,  differences between groups will be assessed by formal p-interaction testing, a p for interaction value of ≤ 0.05 will be deemed statistically significant. We will  examine publication bias using funnel plot. All analyses will be conducted using “Admetan” commands from Stata, 15 (StataCorp. 2017. Stata Statistical Software: Release 15. College Station, TX: StataCorp LLC).

We will utilize the “related articles” function in PubMed to find relevant articles which are missed by the initial search. In addition, reference lists of included studies will be hand searched to further locate relevant articles that are missed by the primary search. Our search and meta-analysis will be conducted and reported according to Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Protocols (PRISMA-P) Statement 2015.  
Study selection: Titles and abstracts of studies will be screened by two authors. The full texts of relevant articles will be reviewed to determine if the study meet the inclusion criteria. Any discrepancies will be resolved by a third author.
Inclusion criteria: To be included in the current analysis, the study has to fulfill all of the following criteria: (1) randomized controlled trial , (2) includes patients with hypertension treated by RSD, (3) control group treated by sham procedure, (4) reported the outcomes of interest. (4) study is in English language and full text published in peer-review journal.
Outcomes and definitions: The outcomes of interest will include: (1) change in 24-hour ambulatory systolic blood pressure (ASBP), (2) change in 24-hour ambulatory diastolic blood pressure (ADBP), (3) change in office systolic blood pressure (OSBP), (4) change in office diastolic blood pressure(ODBP). All the outcomes were analyzed at the maximum follow up provided by the included RCTs.
Quality assessment: The methodological quality and risk of bias of included studies will be evaluated using the Cochrane Collaboration’s tool for risk of bias. 
Statistical analysis: The meta-analysis outcomes will be pooled using Mantel-Hansel random effects model. DerSimonian and Laird method will be used for estimation of heterogeneity. We will use the random effect model to account for potential statistical heterogeneity. Summary estimates will be calculated as weighted mean difference (WMD) with 95% confidence intervals (CI). Sensitivity analysis will be performed on primary outcomes by exclusion of one trial at a time. Heterogeneity between studies will be explored by Cochran Q statistic (p<0.05) and I-squared (I2) statistic. All statistical tests will be two-sided and P values <0.05 will be considered significant.   
 To account for heterogeneity  in study designs, we will stratify our analysis  based on  following categories  of studies : (a)  based on medication status by dividing the studies into those which allowed the patients to be on antihypertensive medications (ON Medication) versus studies which mandated all patients to be off antihypertensive medications (OFF Medication) and (b)  based on the whether a first generation monopolar catheter versus second generation multipolar  catheter was used  (First versus Second generation trials). Furthermore, to study the effect of difference in duration of follow up between the trials , we will perform an additional analysis looking at the heterogeneity of the treatment effect by dividing the studies into two groups, studies which report outcomes at > 3 month of follow-up versus studies reporting the outcomes at ≤ 3 month of follow up,  differences between groups will be assessed by formal p-interaction testing, a p for interaction value of ≤ 0.05 will be deemed statistically significant. We will  examine publication bias using funnel plot. All analyses will be conducted using “Admetan” commands from Stata, 15 (StataCorp. 2017. Stata Statistical Software: Release 15. College Station, TX: StataCorp LLC).

attributes.title: The effects of a temporal processing-based auditory training program on the auditory skills of elderly users of hearing aids: a study protocol for a randomized clinical trial
attributes.description:
Background: One of the most important effects of age-related declines in neural processing speed is the impairment of temporal resolution, which leads to difficulty hearing in noisy environments. Since the central auditory system is highly plastic, by designing and implementing a temporal processing-based auditory training program, we can help the elderly improve their listening skills and speech understanding in noisy environments.
Methods: In the first phase of this research, based on the theoretical framework of temporal processing, an auditory training solution was developed as a software program. In the second phase, which will be described in the present study, the effects of the designed program on the listening skills of the elderly users of hearing aids (age: 60-75 years) will be studied in the control and intervention groups. In the intervention group, the auditory training program will be implemented for three months (36 sessions), and the results of central tests (GIN, DPT, QuickSIN) and the electrophysiological speech-ABR test will be compared in both groups before, immediately and one month after the intervention.
Discussion: Since temporal processing is not sufficient in auditory training programs for the elderly with hearing impairments, implementation of a temporal processing-based auditory training program can reduce hearing problems in noisy environments among elderly users of hearing aids.

q2.value: Since temporal processing is not sufficient in auditory training programs for the elderly with hearing impairments, implementation of a temporal processing-based auditory training program can reduce hearing problems in noisy environments among elderly users of hearing aids.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This clinical trial protocol is the second part of a larger research project. In the first part, the intervention was developed based on the theoretical framework of temporal processing, which is available as an auditory-based training software program (at home PC-based training program). In the second part (simple randomized clinical trial), the effect of the designed training program will be examined. For this purpose, authors will evaluate 60-75 years-old elderly with hearing loss, who live in Tehran and are referred to the Audiology Clinic of the Rehabilitation School of Iran University of Medical Sciences with more than three months of experience in using binaural hearing aids and will be selected based on the inclusion criteria for entering the study.

q7.value: The participants will be randomly divided into two groups. The intervention group will participate in the auditory training program, while the control group will not be involved in the auditory training program; both groups will be matched for age and gender. For this purpose, random numbers are assigned to individuals based on a random number table. Subjects with odd numbers are assigned to the control group, while those with even numbers are assigned to the intervention group. This process will be carried out by an audiology department employee, who is not involved in the study. Allocation concealment will be performed by random allocation cards using computer-generated random numbers.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
For this purpose, authors will evaluate 60-75 years-old elderly with hearing loss, who live in Tehran and are referred to the Audiology Clinic of the Rehabilitation School of Iran University of Medical Sciences with more than three months of experience in using binaural hearing aids and will be selected based on the inclusion criteria for entering the study.
Inclusion criteria
The inclusion criteria are as follows: 1) age range of 60-75 years; 2) mild to moderate bilateral sensorineural hearing loss; 3) mean hearing threshold of 40-55 dBHL (averaged over 0.5, 1, 2, and 4 kHz) in both ears; 4) bilateral hearing loss; 5) use of binaural hearing aids for more than three months; 6) normal middle ear function30; 7) lack of cognitive problems based on the results of Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)31; 8) having a high-school diploma or higher; 9) right-handedness based on the Edinburgh Handedness Inventory32; and 10) being a monolingual (Farsi).
 
Exclusion criteria
Unwillingness to cooperate with the study at any stage and failure to meet any of the inclusion criteria.

The used tests do not cause any complications for the participants, and the participants can withdraw from the study at any stage. All auditory training examinations and sessions are free of charge. Participants with knowledge of objects and details of the research are included after obtaining their written informed consent by one of the researchers of this study. The consent form is provided as Extended data41. The confidentiality of data will be respected during the study as explained in the consent form. If the results are positive, the auditory training program will be also implemented for the control group.

question.value:
An ABR test will be performed with a speech stimulus, using the Bio-Logic Navigator Pro System. In this test, a non-inverting electrode is placed at Cz, and the inverting electrode is placed on the right ear lobule, and a ground electrode is placed on the forehead. The impedance value of all electrodes is below 5 kΩ (maximum=1.5 kΩ). The stimulus is a 40-msec synthetic /da/ syllable, used in previous studies by the Auditory Neuroscience Laboratory of Nina Kraus et al.15 at Northwestern University (USA). The test will be performed in a quiet place with closed eyes (or during sleep) while leaning against a comfortable chair in an acoustic room with low light and low ambient noise. No cognitive stimulus will be used during the experiments7.
• Central tests, including gap detection in noise (GIN), duration pattern test (DPT), and QuickSIN, will be performed. These tests are sensitive to the central auditory nervous system (CANS) lesions but are not affected by peripheral hearing loss35.
GIN test: This test consists of a series of 36 different six-second segments of white noise. Each segment contains zero to three gaps of silence. The interval between the noise segments is five seconds, and the duration of silence gaps is 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, 15, and 20 msec. Ten practice items are presented before starting the test. There are four lists available for the test, which allow for a comparison of the tests. Generally, one list is used for each ear. Although the test is run through a single channel, a second channel is also used by the examiner to control and rate the responses. The test includes two criteria for examining the results: 1) a threshold for detecting gaps in noise; and 2) the percentage of correct responses for each ear. The gap detection threshold in noise is considered as the shortest gap duration for which there are four out of six correct responses. The percentage of correct responses is the mean percentage of correct responses during the test36.
DPT test: This test consists of three pure tones in each segment. The frequency of each tone is 1000 Hz, and its duration is either 250 msec (short) or 500 msec (long). The gap between the tones is 300 msec. Generally, there are six patterns for this test (LLS, LSL, LSS, SLS, SLS, SLL, and SSL), and a six-second gap of silence separates the segments. The percentage of correct responses is the mean of all percentages of one's correct responses during the test. It is recommended to perform the test at 50 dB SL to the speech recognition threshold or pure tone average (500, 1000, and 2000 Hz). Since intensity has insignificant effects on test performance, it can be also performed at 10 dBSL36.
QuickSIN test: In general, QuickSIN is a quick test to quantify one’s ability to hear in the presence of noise. It can be performed using headphones and/or free-field speakers (free-field in this study). In this test, a series of sentences are presented to both ears, and at the same time, a babbling noise is presented to both ears; in other words, noise is competitive with the stimulus. This test is performed at the most comfortable level (MCL). The patient's response is written, and the number of correct repeated words is documented in the “results” sheet. A total of five lists are used for each person.
Each list contains six sentences, and each sentence has five keywords, all of which are presented in babble noise. The noise level is set at six levels (preset on CD) and increases in 5-dB steps; in other words, the test conditions gradually become more and more competitive. The signal-to-noise ratios include 25, 20, 15, 10, 5, and 0 dB. At the end of each list, the total number of correct repeated words is recorded, and the signal-to-noise reduction ratio (SNR loss) is calculated30.

First, the Chi-square test will be used to examine the normal distribution of each variable. If data distribution is normal, parametric tests, including paired t-test, independent t-test, and ANCOVA test, will be performed. Otherwise, non-parametric Mann-Whitney and Wilcoxon tests will be carried out. Fisher’s exact test will be applied for the homogeneity of the groups. Statistical analysis will be conducted using SPSS version 22.0 (IBM Corporation, New York, USA), and the significance level is considered to be 0.05.

attributes.title: How Downward Comparison of Immigration Influences Personal Wherewithal
attributes.description:
The aim of this research is to understand how reflecting on discrimination of an ethnic group influences individuals' endorsement of personal wherewithal and neoliberal ideology. 

Neoliberal ideology became common sense amongst many people who believe that the government should be as small as possible and not interfere in the economic market. Neoliberal policies create inequalities between the wealthy and the middle and lower classes. Our aim is to understand if policies against immigrants started by Trump administration influence people's support towards neoliberalism. Because a component of neoliberal ideology is an endorsement of personal wherewithal and a disagreement with government interference. As well as not seeing a system of inequality among people through race, gender, and class.

q2.value: The hypothesis of this study is that individuals who are primed to consider discrimination at the border will have decreased senses of personal wherewithal and neoliberal beliefs compared to those who are not primed, measured based on individual questionnaires of the two measures.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The research design of this study is an experimental design. In conducting an experimental design, we can see between two groups, specifically those that are exposed to ethnic discrimination and those that are not to see if there is indeed a significant difference in personal wherewithal, government interference, and system inequality. All of these three categories relate back to neoliberalism and help us understand the individual differences that people may have if exposed to ethnic discrimination and how that may affect their endorsement of neoliberal ideology. 

To analyze the results the PI will use a t-test, factor analysis, and regression in order to understand which beliefs best reflect the differences of neoliberal attitudes.

q7.value: Block randomization will be utilized. Each participant will be randomly assigned to one out of the two groups, with equal distribution. The distribution system being used, Qualtrics, randomly assigns participants to one of the groups.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants must confirm that they are at least 18 years of age (through the consent form). We will be using multiple recruitment methods that will bring a diverse sample. Participants will be recruited through:
• Online social networking sites such as Instagram, Twitter, Reddit, etc. 
• Amazon Mechanical Turk
• Through snowball methodologies (participants will be invited to invite their friends to answer the survey).
• We will also use the psychology department research pool at CSUF

q11.value: Our target sample size is 110 participants.

q12.value: Our effect size (Cohen's d) was .71, giving us a G*Power analysis of 110. This, however, is not sufficient, so we are looking to recruit 200 people.

q13.value: Through Qualtrics, we can limit the amount of responses to 200.

question.value: The variable that will be manipulated will be exposure to ethnic discrimination. Essentially, those who are exposed to an ethnic discrimination narrative prior to participating in the target surveys versus those who are exposed after taking the surveys.

We will measure the participants' responses on both a personal wherewithal scale and an anti-government (neoliberal) survey. An example of an item on the personal wherewithal survey is "Any goal can be achieved with enough hard work and talent", with the answers ranging from "Strongly Disagree" to "Strongly Agree". An example of an item on the anti-government survey is "The government is inefficient, and therefore should not interfere with the private sector", with answers ranging from "Strongly Disagree" to "Strongly Agree".
To analyze the results the PI will use a t-test and regression in order to understand which beliefs best reflect the differences of neoliberal attitudes.

q18.value: Participants will be coded by Group 1 (0.0), being the control group and Group 2 (1.0), being the experimental group.

q21.value: If the participant does not complete the surveys, they will be excluded from the study.

q22.value: We assume that certain demographic traits (specifically, social class and Latinx people) may relate to personal wherewithal and neoliberal beliefs.

q23.value: We utilized Laina Y. Bay-Cheng's anti-government scale.

attributes.title: Supplemental materials for preprint: All journal articles evaluating the origin or epidemiology of SARS-CoV-2 that utilize the RaTG13 bat strain genomics are potentially flawed and should be retracted.
attributes.description: Recent SARS-CoV-2 epidemiological origin studies have made their conclusion based-in-part by analyzing a bat coronavirus strain that most closely matches SARS-CoV-2 called RaTG13. However, the origins of this strain are obfuscated and therefore the genomics of the strain cannot be trusted, especially in context of determining the origin of SARS-CoV-2.

summary.value: This study reveals that a bat coronavirus strain that the Wuhan Institute of Virology found that most closely matches SARS-CoV-2, called RaTG13, is actually an earlier strain the Wuhan Institute of Virology  found in 2013 called BtCoV/4991. A BLAST genomic analysis shows a 100% genome match.

registration_responses.summary: This study reveals that a bat coronavirus strain that the Wuhan Institute of Virology found that most closely matches SARS-CoV-2, called RaTG13, is actually an earlier strain the Wuhan Institute of Virology  found in 2013 called BtCoV/4991. A BLAST genomic analysis shows a 100% genome match.

attributes.title: PAS V2:  Progressive Alignment + Verbs, iPad study
attributes.description: This study with asks whether children benefit from seeing similar events that can be compared while learning a verb, even when events are separated by a delay.

q1.value: Progressive Alignment Study - Extension of prior work

q3.value: Prior studies show children are able to learn new verbs by hearing a verb repeated across three events in a learning phase.  This study examines whether the degree of similarity between events, time delay, and distracting information affect children's performance on this task. We investigate how these factors interact to influence how accurately children are able to identify the learned verb at test.

q4.value: Children who see two events that are highly similar will perform better than children who see events that are varied.  The abiity to compare across events when they are separated by a 1 minute delay may develop.  We predict that our youngest children (2 1/2-year-olds) may fail in both conditions because they may not be able to compare events separated in time.  However, 3 1/2-year-olds should be able to compare across time, but may benefit from seeing the similar events.  Four 1/2-year-olds are predicted to succeed in both conditions. Performance on the verb learning task will correlate with performance on executive functioning tasks (Bear/Dragon and Day/Night).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Videotaped records of experimental sessions are coded by a research assistant who was not present for the original session, and are second coded by a second new research assistant.  Neither coder has access to the other codings.  Interrater reliability is calculated between these two coders.

question.value:
2-by-3 between-subjects factor design for each group (progressive alignment (PA) vs. all far (AF), by Age (2s, 3s, 4s). In PA, all 3 learning events are similar to each other whereas in AF, 2 events are similar to each other and the 3rd is dissimilar. All children experience a 1-minute delay.  They watch a 1-minute distractor clip after each of the learning videos.  

A follow-up condition may be run with selected age groups who will have no delay (e.g., 2 1/2-year-olds) if they fail in the main study.

q9.value: Within each age group, participants are randomly assigned to one of the four experimental conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Some preliminary analyses of the data have been conducted, but no study parameters have been altered, including sample size.  We have not performed the final analysis with the full sample.

question.value: Participants are recruited from local daycares. Parents are sent a letter describing the study and returned signed consent forms to teachers if interested. Children are excluded if parents report that they hear a language other than English more than 30% of the time, or teachers report that they have a language delay.  We have been collecting data for several semesters.  Children and teachers receive various gifts (t-shirts, gift bags, ice cream) for their involvement as we complete data collection at their site.  All participants are between 2 and 5 years of age.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 120 participants, 40 in each age group (2's, 3's and 4's) so that 10 can be assigned to each of the four conditions.

q14.value: Our goal is to detect any differences between age groups and between conditions, as well as differences from performance at chance level, at the .05 level of significance.

q15.value: We recruit participants from local daycares, rotating between them across the year. We will continue to run participants until we reach the desired number for each age and condition.

question.value: We manipulate the degree of similarity between learning events using the progressive alignment (PA) and all far (AF) conditions. In PA, all 3 learning events are similar to each other whereas in AF, 2 events are similar to each other and the 3rd is dissimilar. In the 1-minute delay condition children watch a 1-minute distractor clip after each of the learning videos. In the no delay condition children watch the 3 learning events back-to-back.

We record whether participants correctly point in both directions during a warm up phase in an effort to detect side bias. We will measure whether participants correctly point to the action representing the learned verb at test. Correct and incorrect responses on the secondary tasks (bear/dragon, day/night) are recorded as a covariate to explain variation within each age-condition group.

Within each age-condition we calculate the percentage of the time that participants pointed correctly. For the secondary tasks we calculate the percentage of the time that participants responded correctly.

For 3- and 4-year-olds, we will use a 2 (Age: 3, 4) x 2 (Condition: PA, AF) ANOVA, with proportion correct at test as the dv.  

For 2 1/2-year-olds, who are predicted to fail in the delay condition, we will use a 2 x 2 ANOVA with Condition (PA, AF) and delay (no delay, 1 minute delay) as factors; dv= proportion correct.  

Post hoc analyses will be run to detect differences in pointing accuracy between individual conditions.

Performance on the bear/dragon and day/night tasks may either be entered as a covariate in the main analyses or we will compute a correlation to see if proportion correct correlates with higher scores on these EF tasks.

q20.value: Percentage pointing accuracy does not require any additional transformations.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.  Tukey and/or Bonferroni tests will be used as post-hoc analyses.

q22.value: We exclude participants for any of the following reasons: experimenter error, excessive fussiness, failure to respond during warm-up phase. The only potential outlier to consider is side bias, i.e. when children point in the same direction for each trial; we choose not to exclude these children because we interpret them as responding at chance.

q23.value: We will not include in our analysis any participants for whom we are missing data.

q24.value: It is possible that demographic variables (ethnicity, gender) are related to performance on the tasks and we will test for any such effects.

registration_responses.q1: Progressive Alignment Study - Extension of prior work
registration_responses.q3: Prior studies show children are able to learn new verbs by hearing a verb repeated across three events in a learning phase.  This study examines whether the degree of similarity between events, time delay, and distracting information affect children's performance on this task. We investigate how these factors interact to influence how accurately children are able to identify the learned verb at test.
registration_responses.q4: Children who see two events that are highly similar will perform better than children who see events that are varied.  The abiity to compare across events when they are separated by a 1 minute delay may develop.  We predict that our youngest children (2 1/2-year-olds) may fail in both conditions because they may not be able to compare events separated in time.  However, 3 1/2-year-olds should be able to compare across time, but may benefit from seeing the similar events.  Four 1/2-year-olds are predicted to succeed in both conditions. Performance on the verb learning task will correlate with performance on executive functioning tasks (Bear/Dragon and Day/Night).

attributes.title: Psychological Antecedents of Consumer Self-development
attributes.description: Revision to original data screening procedure. No analyses have been conducted.

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

outliers.value:
Original preregistered data screening procedure: 

Duplicate participant IDs will be identified and the second entry removed. Any participant who withdraws based on the exit consent will be removed. Data screening prior to any analyses will be conducted on the following attention/quality checks: (a) the Conscientious Responder scale, where three out of five items must be correctly answered; (b) responding “yes” to the self-report attention check item; (c) correct responses to the single item comprehension check; (d) any participant who uses a single response throughout will be removed (e.g., responding with all “1’s”); (e) no greater than a 5 minute break between the manipulation and the outcome measures, (f) screen out if participants who do not meaningfully respond to the “saying is believing” task (in other words, participants must follow the instructions); and (g) reading speed (i.e., reading more than 300 wpm; Brysbaert, 2019). 

Deviation from preregistered data screening procedure:

Upon screening out poor quality responses based on the above criteria, it was observed that one comprehension check item (item c, above) removed ~half the sample. 

The item was “Did the [at-home kit] include instructional videos?” (responses: yes, no, don’t remember).

Only 56.9% passed the check by correctly responding “yes." 44 participants (18.4%) failed this check by selecting “no.” The remaining 59 participants (24.7%) selected “could not remember.”

We are therefore excluding this comprehension check from the data screening procedure on the basis that this check too strictly removes participants. 

There have been no other deviations from the data screening procedure. No analyses have been performed at this point.

attributes.title: Balloon Occlusion of the Aorta Compared to Conventional Blood Management Techniques for Sacral Tumour Resection: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Surgical Outcomes

summary.value:
1. * Review title.
 
Balloon Occlusion of the Aorta Compared to Conventional Blood Management Techniques for Sacral Tumour Resection: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Surgical Outcomes

2. * Stage of review at time of this submission.

Review stage	- Completed
Preliminary searches - Completed	
Piloting of the study selection process - Completed		
Formal screening of search results against eligibility criteria - Ongoing	
Data extraction - Not started
Risk of bias (quality) assessment - Not started		
Data analysis - Not started		

3. * Named contact.
 
Adrian Bailey

4. * Named contact email.

abail082@uottawa.ca

5. Named contact phone number.

6138585029

6. * Organizational affiliation of the review.

University of Ottawa

The Ottawa Hospital

7. * Review team members and their organizational affiliations.
 
•	Mr Adrian Bailey. University of Ottawa
•	Mr Alex Lee. University of Ottawa
•	Ms Heidi Li. University of Ottawa
•	Dr Peter Glen. The Ottawa Hospital, Division of General Surgery

8. * Funding sources/sponsors.

None

9. * Conflicts of interest.
 
None
 
10. * Review question.
 
How does intra-operative balloon occlusion of the aorta compare to conventional blood management techniques used in sacral tumour resection with respect to surgical outcomes?

P: Patients that require and are eligible for sacral tumour resection
I: Intra-operative balloon occlusion of the aorta
C: Conventional surgical techniques
O: Surgical outcomes: total blood loss, intra-operative blood loss, post-operative blood loss, operation time, transfusion volume, morbidity, mortality, adverse events, complications, recurrence of malignancy.

11. * Searches.
 
PubMed and Scopus will be searched on February 17th, 2020. Studies from 1950-2020 will be included. The search will combine the following key words; tumour, balloon, and occlusion. We will include all English-language full-text articles that compared intra-operative aortic balloon occlusion in sacral tumour surgery to conventional surgery controls. The studies are required to be comparative, with the experimental group receiving aortic balloon occlusion and the control group receiving conventional treatment.

12. * Condition or domain being studied.

Sacral and pelvic tumour resection surgeries are associated with significant intra- and post-operative bleeding. Although intra-aortic balloon occlusion or resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion has re-emerged as an acute tool for controlling hemorrhage from trauma, its use in elective surgeries has not yet been thoroughly conducted. While studies have published the effects of prophylactic intra-aortic balloon occlusion as a mean of decreasing blood loss in sacropelvic tumour resections, these are few and are generally small cohort retrospective studies or case series. Yet, published results are promising and show significant improvements in blood loss and transfusion amount. We propose reviewing the current literature on the surgical outcomes of prophylactic intra-aortic balloon occlusion during sacral and pelvic tumour surgery in a meta-analysis.

13. * Participants/population.
 
Inclusion:
-Patients with sacral tumours requiring surgical resection receiving aortic balloon occlusion intra-operatively for control of blood loss.

Exclusion:
-Patients under 18 years of age.
-Patients requiring surgery for any other condition, including acetabular fracture, abdominal aortic aneurysm, gynecological bleeding, and trauma.

14. * Intervention(s), exposure(s).
 
Intervention: Intra-operative balloon occlusion of the aorta during sacral tumour resection.

Intra-aortic balloon occlusion (IABO), or resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion of the aorta (REBOA), was first utilized in the Korean War to treat uncontrolled intra-abdominal hemorrhage, and its use is expanding to a range of different traumatic and non-traumatic indications. This technique involves advancing a compliant balloon into the aorta and inflating it to obstruct blood flow into the distal circulation. In pelvic and sacral tumour surgery, an IABO device can be inserted prophylactically to control bleeding that may occur distal to the iliac bifurcation with handling and resection of the tumour. This presumably maintains hemodynamic stability and improves view of the operative field.

15. * Comparator(s)/control.
 
Comparator: Patients receiving conventional surgery for sacral tumour resection.

Inclusion:
-Patients receiving conventional surgery for sacral tumour resection.

Exclusion:
-Patients under 18 years of age.
-Patients receiving surgery for acetabular fracture, abdominal aortic aneurysm, trauma, and other applications of aortic balloon occlusion.
-Patients receiving intra-operative balloon occlusion peri-operatively.

16. * Types of study to be included.
 
Inclusion Criteria:
-Studies reporting on the use of balloon occlusion of the aorta during sacral tumour resection. 
-Eligible study designs include retrospective cohort, prospective cohort, randomized controlled trials (RCT), and randomized clinical trials.

Exclusion Criteria:
-Case reports, case series, gray literature, and review articles are excluded.
-Studies reporting on surgery for acetabular fracture, abdominal aortic aneurysm, trauma, and other applications of aortic balloon occlusion.

17. * Main outcome(s).
 
Main outcomes:
i) Blood loss intra-operatively
ii) Post-operative blood loss
iii) Total blood loss
iv) Total transfusion volume
v) Operation time
vi) Mortality

Timing and effect measures:

Timing = peri- and post- intervention

Effect measure = standardized mean difference with random effects model

18. * Additional outcome(s).
 
i) Morbidity
ii) Adverse events
iii) Complications
iv) Recurrence of tumours

Timing and effect measures:
Timing = peri- and post- intervention

Effect measure = standardized mean difference with random effects model

19. * Data extraction (selection and coding).

Study selection
• Two independent, blinded reviewers will apply the inclusion and exclusion criteria to select studies for inclusion into the systematic review. Discrepancies will be resolved by a third reviewer, the supervisor of the study.
• Excel software will be used to record decisions.
Data extraction
• Information about and not limited to study design and methodology, participant demographics and baseline characteristics, and adverse events will be recorded. Study authors will not be contacted for additional information.
• Two independent, blinded reviewers will extract data from select studies. Less than 5% error between reviewers will be acceptable in cases where estimation is required (i.e., using ImageJ software to estimate values from Figures when the data is not reported in text or supplemental materials). Discrepancies will be resolved by a third reviewer, the supervisor of the study.
• Excel software will be used to record data.

20. * Risk of bias (quality) assessment.
 
Methods for assessing risk of bias reported in systematic review protocols should include:
• The Cochrane risk of bias tool for randomised trials, version 2.0, will be used to assess the risk of bias of all included prospective studies.
• The ROBINS-I tool for non-randomised studies will be used to assess retrospective and case-control studies.
• Two independent, blinded reviewers will use these tools to assess the risk of bias and quality of studies. Discrepancies will be resolved by a third reviewer, the supervisor of the study.
• Assessment will be done at the study level.

21. * Strategy for data synthesis.

• Data will only be synthesized if there are more than two studies that report on the same outcome.
• Outcomes will be analyzed and plotted separately.
• Outcomes that will attempted to be synthesized will include blood loss intra and post operatively, total blood loss, transfusion volume, operation time, adverse events, morbidity, mortality.
• The standardized mean difference in a random-effects meta-analysis for quantitative data will be used to pool data for continuous outcomes (blood loss intra and post operatively, total blood loss, transfusion volume). Odd’s ratio will be used for dichotomous outcomes (adverse events, morbidity, mortality). Only outcomes with low to moderate heterogeneity will be considered to be interpretable. All analysis will be reported.

22. * Analysis of subgroups or subsets.
 
Subgroup analysis is not planned.

23. * Country.

•	Canada

24. Dissemination plans.
 
Publication to a surgical journal indexed in PubMed.

Do you intend to publish the review on completion?

Yes

25. Keywords.

Balloon; Aortic; Occlusion; Blood; Management; Sacral; Pelvis; Tumour; Resection
